anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who win road march in trinidad and tobago
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.\n', 'Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.\n', 'Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.\n', "Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).\n", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.\n', 'On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. \n', 'In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. \n', '• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013\n', 'First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910\'s to 1930\'s. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. \n', 'In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question regarding who has won the Road March title in Trinidad and Tobago, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content and its significance:

1. **Historical Context of the Road March**:
   - The Road March title has been awarded annually since 1932, with exceptions during World War I and World War II. This establishes the longstanding tradition and importance of the competition within Trinidad and Tobago's Carnival culture.

2. **Eligibility Rules**:
   - Initially, the Road March title was won by a German pop song in 1955, which led to a rule change that restricted eligibility to songs by local Trinidad and Tobago artists. This highlights the cultural significance of the competition and the emphasis on local artistry.

3. **Notable Winners**:
   - **Lord Kitchener**: Holds the record for the most wins with eleven titles.
   - **Super Blue** and **Machel Montano**: Each has ten wins, showcasing their prominence in the soca genre.
   - **Calypso Rose**: The first female winner in 1977, which marks a significant milestone in the competition's history, indicating the evolving role of women in calypso music.
   - **Fay-Ann Lyons**: A three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and notable for being the first female to win multiple titles, as well as achieving a unique triple win in 2009. Her achievements illustrate the potential for female artists to excel in a traditionally male-dominated field.

4. **Recent Developments**:
   - In 2019, **Skinny Fabulous** became the first foreign soca artist to win the Road March title with the song "Famalay." This indicates a shift in the competition's landscape, allowing for international participation and recognition.

5. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The Road March title is described as one of the most prestigious awards in Trinidad Carnival, emphasizing its importance in the cultural and social fabric of Trinidad and Tobago.

### Role of Extracted Content:
- **Cultural Understanding**: The historical context and eligibility rules provide insight into the cultural significance of the Road March and its evolution over time.
- **Recognition of Artists**: Highlighting notable winners helps to understand the competitive landscape and the impact of these artists on the genre of soca and calypso music.
- **Gender Dynamics**: The achievements of female artists like Calypso Rose and Fay-Ann Lyons illustrate the changing dynamics within the music scene, promoting inclusivity and recognition of women's contributions.
- **International Influence**: The recent win by a foreign artist indicates globalization's impact on local traditions, suggesting that the Road March is not only a national event but also gaining international attention.

In summary, the extracted content provides a comprehensive background that enhances understanding of the Road March competition, its significance, and the artists involved, which is essential for answering the question about its winners.

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. Identify points of agreement and disagreement among the experts, and analyze how these differing perspectives contribute to a deeper understanding of the topic. Synthesize the insights from the discussion into a cohesive summary that captures the full range of foundational and advanced knowledge. Highlight how these perspectives expand the understanding of the question.

By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on the Trinidad and Tobago Road March Title**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
The Road March title has a rich history dating back to 1932, with interruptions during the World Wars. Initially referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways," the term "Road March" was adopted in 1946. This historical evolution is crucial for understanding the cultural significance of the title in Trinidad Carnival. The fact that the first official winners were not local artists, as seen with the Obernkirchen Children’s Choir in 1955, led to the amendment of rules to ensure that only local talent could compete. This highlights the importance of local culture in the preservation of the Carnival's identity.

**Expert 2: Gender and Representation Advocate**
The Road March title has seen significant milestones in terms of gender representation. Calypso Rose's victories in the late 1970s marked a turning point for female artists in a male-dominated genre. Her wins not only paved the way for other female artists but also led to the renaming of the "Calypso King" competition to "Calypso Monarch," reflecting a more inclusive approach. Fay-Ann Lyons' three wins further underscore the growing recognition of female talent in this space, especially as she achieved this while pregnant, breaking stereotypes about women in performance arts.

**Expert 3: Contemporary Trends Analyst**
The recent win by Skinny Fabulous in 2019 as the first foreign soca artist to claim the Road March title with "Famalay" indicates a shift in the competition's landscape. This suggests that the Road March is evolving beyond its traditional confines, embracing a more global perspective. The collaboration between local and foreign artists can be seen as a blending of cultures, which may enrich the Carnival experience but also raises questions about the authenticity of local representation.

**Expert 4: Soca and Calypso Musicologist**
The Road March title is not just a competition; it reflects the evolution of Trinidadian music genres, particularly calypso and soca. The scoring system, which is based on a register-and-count method, emphasizes the popularity of songs during the Carnival parade. Artists like Machel Montano, who has multiple wins, exemplify the blend of traditional calypso with contemporary soca, showcasing how the genre has adapted over time. The competition serves as a barometer for the changing tastes of the Trinidadian public.

**Points of Agreement:**
- All experts agree on the cultural significance of the Road March title within Trinidad Carnival and its role in promoting local talent.
- There is a consensus on the importance of gender representation, with acknowledgment of both Calypso Rose and Fay-Ann Lyons as pivotal figures in this regard.
- The evolution of the competition, particularly with the inclusion of foreign artists, is recognized as a trend that could redefine the future of the Road March.

**Points of Disagreement:**
- Some experts express concern that the inclusion of foreign artists might dilute the local essence of the competition, while others argue that it enhances cultural exchange and diversity.
- The interpretation of the scoring system's impact on the competition's integrity varies, with some viewing it as a fair representation of popularity and others seeing it as potentially favoring commercial over artistic merit.

**Cohesive Summary:**
The Trinidad and Tobago Road March title is a prestigious accolade steeped in history, reflecting the evolution of local music and culture. While it has traditionally celebrated local artists, recent developments, including the wins by foreign artists, suggest a shift towards a more inclusive and global perspective. The contributions of female artists have been transformative, challenging gender norms and expanding the scope of representation within the genre. As the competition continues to evolve, it remains a vital expression of Trinidadian identity, balancing tradition with contemporary influences. This multifaceted discussion highlights the complexities surrounding cultural representation, authenticity, and the future trajectory of the Road March in Trinidad and Tobago.

Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.
', 'Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.
', 'Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.
', "Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).
", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.
', 'On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. 
', 'In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. 
', '• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013
', 'First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910's to 1930's. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children's Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. 
', 'In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages about the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition. Here’s a summary of the key points:

### Extracted Information:

1. **Historical Context**:
   - The Road March title has been awarded annually since 1932, with exceptions during World War I and World War II.
   - The competition was rebranded from "Leggos" or "Breakaways" to "Road March" in 1946.

2. **Eligibility Rules**:
   - Initially, songs could be from any artist, but after a German song won in 1955, rules were amended to restrict eligibility to local Trinidad and Tobago artists.

3. **Notable Winners**:
   - The late Lord Kitchener holds the record with eleven wins.
   - Super Blue and Machel Montano each have ten wins.
   - Calypso Rose was the first female winner in 1977 and won again in 1978.
   - Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the first female to win multiple titles.
   - In 2019, Skinny Fabulous became the first foreign soca artist to win with "Famalay."

4. **Competition Structure**:
   - The scoring system is based on a register-and-count method devised by a Carnival committee.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The historical context provides a timeline that helps the model understand how events (like the introduction of new rules) can change the outcomes of competitions (e.g., restricting eligibility to local artists).
   - The information about notable winners and their achievements can help the model infer patterns of success and the impact of gender on competition outcomes (e.g., Calypso Rose breaking through in a male-dominated field).

2. **Logical Inference**:
   - The rules and scoring methods allow the model to make logical deductions about how winners are determined and the significance of local versus foreign participation.
   - By analyzing the frequency of wins among artists, the model can infer the competitive landscape of the Road March and the factors contributing to repeated successes (e.g., popularity, style of music).

3. **Pattern Recognition**:
   - The model can recognize patterns in the types of songs that win (e.g., soca vs. calypso) and the demographics of winners (e.g., gender representation over time).
   - The mention of specific years and events allows the model to create a causal chain of events leading to changes in the competition, such as the introduction of female artists and their impact on the competition's dynamics.

### Conclusion:

By consolidating this information, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities by understanding the relationships between historical events, rule changes, and outcomes in the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition. This understanding can be applied to broader contexts where rules, eligibility, and competition dynamics play a crucial role in determining outcomes.

To determine who won the Road March in Trinidad and Tobago, we must understand the significance of the event within the Carnival season. The Road March title is awarded to the song that is played most frequently during the parade, and the winner is typically announced after the Carnival festivities conclude. 

1. **Historical Context**: The Road March title has been awarded annually since 1932, with interruptions during World War I and World War II. This historical context helps us understand the longevity and tradition of the competition.

2. **Eligibility Rules**: Initially, songs from any artist could win, but after a German song won in 1955, the rules were changed to allow only local Trinidad and Tobago artists. This change emphasizes the importance of local culture in the competition.

3. **Notable Winners**: 
   - The late Lord Kitchener holds the record with eleven wins, showcasing a pattern of success among certain artists.
   - Super Blue and Machel Montano each have ten wins, indicating their significant impact on the genre.
   - Calypso Rose was the first female winner in 1977, breaking gender barriers in a male-dominated field, and she won again in 1978.
   - Fay-Ann Lyons is notable for being a three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the first female to achieve multiple titles.
   - In 2019, Skinny Fabulous became the first foreign soca artist to win with "Famalay," illustrating the evolving nature of the competition.

4. **Competition Structure**: The scoring system is based on a register-and-count method devised by a Carnival committee, which provides a structured approach to determining the winner.

### Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

- **Understanding Causality**: The historical context and rule changes illustrate how external factors (like the success of a foreign song) can lead to significant changes in competition rules, thereby affecting future outcomes.
- **Logical Inference**: The frequency of wins among artists allows us to infer trends in musical styles and audience preferences over time. For instance, the dominance of soca music in recent years can be linked to the popularity of artists like Machel Montano and Fay-Ann Lyons.
- **Pattern Recognition**: The model can identify patterns in the types of songs that win and the demographics of winners, which can inform predictions about future competitions. For example, the success of female artists in recent years may suggest a shift in audience preferences and acceptance.

### Conclusion:

By synthesizing this information, the model can enhance its understanding of the relationships between historical events, rule changes, and outcomes in the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition. passages:
After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children's Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.
Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.
Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.
Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).
Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.
On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. 
In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. 
• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013
First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910's to 1930's. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children's Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin.
